justification: A cross-sectional online survey with the University students' panel (N = 434) was conducted in March 2021 to explore university students' intentions to be vaccinated and select the most relevant determinants and their underlying beliefs to facilitate informed decision-making around COVID-19 vaccine uptake.

topic_or_construct: concerns about safety and side effects of the vaccine
justification: The online survey identified concerns about safety and side effects of the vaccine as one of the most relevant determinants of vaccine intention, with example questions such as “I am worried about the safety of the COVID-19 vaccine”.

topic_or_construct: trust in the government, quality control, pharmaceutical industry
justification: The survey also included items to measure trust in various entities related to the vaccine, with statements like “I trust the government about ensuring the safety of the COVID-19 vaccine” and “I trust the pharmaceutical industry about the safety of the COVID-19 vaccine.”

The online survey included items to measure risk perception, such as “I think that without vaccination, I might be at risk of contracting COVID-19,” which was identified as a predictor of vaccination intention.
The survey captured attitudes with questions like “I think that getting the COVID-19 vaccine is a way out of this pandemic,” indicating its role in influencing vaccination behavior.

Perceived norms were assessed using items such as “I think that most people who are important to me want me to get the COVID-19 vaccination,” as part of the online survey to understand social influences on vaccination.

The survey included statements for assessing self-efficacy such as “I am confident that before I decide to get the COVID-19 vaccine, I will have sufficient information about the COVID-19 vaccine,” reflecting students' confidence in their ability to navigate the vaccination process.
